t: Job 14
“Mortals,*pn born of woman, are*ld of few days and full of trouble.
They*ln spring up like flowers and wither away; like*ld fleeting shadows, they do not endure.
Do*ln you fix your eye on them? Will*ld you bring them before you for judgment?
Who*ln can bring what is pure from the impure? No*ld one!
A*ln person’s days are determined; you*ld have decreed the number of his months and*ld have set limits he cannot exceed.
So*ln look away from him and let him alone, till*ld he has put in his time like a hired laborer.
“At*pn least there is hope for a tree: If*ld it is cut down, it will sprout again, and*ld its new shoots will not fail.
Its*ln roots may grow old in the ground and*ld its stump die in the soil,
yet*ln at the scent of water it will bud and*ld put forth shoots like a plant.
But*ln a man dies and is laid low; he*ld breathes his last and is no more.
As*ln the water of a lake dries up or*ld a riverbed becomes parched and dry,
so*ln he lies down and does not rise; till*ld the heavens are no more, people will not awake or*ld be roused from their sleep.
“If*pn only you would hide me in the grave and*ld conceal me till your anger has passed! If*ln only you would set me a time and*ld then remember me!
If*ln someone dies, will they live again? All*ld the days of my hard service I*ld will wait for my renewal to come.
You*ln will call and I will answer you; you*ld will long for the creature your hands have made.
Surely*ln then you will count my steps but*ld not keep track of my sin.
My*ln offenses will be sealed up in a bag; you*ld will cover over my sin.
“But*pn as a mountain erodes and crumbles and*ld as a rock is moved from its place,
as*ln water wears away stones and*ld torrents wash away the soil, so*ld you destroy a person’s hope.
You*ln overpower them once for all, and they are gone; you*ld change their countenance and send them away.
If*ln their children are honored, they do not know it; if*ld their offspring are brought low, they do not see it.
They*ln feel but the pain of their own bodies and*ld mourn only for themselves.”
